p: In order to infect a host (cell) and replicate, MERS-CoV has to deliver its genome into the cellular cytoplasm for gene translation and genome replication. This process is facilitated by the viral spike (S) glycoprotein, a type-I transmembrane protein embedded in the viral envelope. For host cell entry, the surface unit, S1, of MERS-CoV S binds to the cellular type-II transmembrane protein dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4, CD26) [ 15]. The structure of the interface between DPP4 and MERS-CoV-S was resolved on the atomic level and fifteen residues in DPP4 were found to make direct contact with residues in the viral S protein [ 16]. Upon DPP4 engagement, MERS-CoV S undergoes proteolytic activation through the cellular serine protease TMPRSS2 or the endosomal cysteine protease cathepsin L [ 17â€“19], which allows the transmembrane unit, S2, of MERS-CoV S to fuse the viral membrane with cellular membranes.
